Award.AwardTitle: University of Pennsylvania RTG in Mathematical Physics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project vertically integrates research and training in Mathematical Physics, Geometry, and String Theory at the Mathematics Department of the University of Pennsylvania. The Penn group will undertake a series of training activities including graduate summer schools, research and outreach workshops, the development of new graduate and undergraduate courses, and preparation of course materials, including a graduate textbook. In parallel, three vertical research projects will be developed: the exciting new connections between the Geometric Langlands Program and dualities in quantum field theory and string theory; a geometric and numerical investigation of the action of the renormalization group flow on the moduli of supersymmetric quantum field theories; and an exploration of special holonomy metrics. The group will create a fertile educational environment that will introduce US students of various preparation levels to cutting edge research questions in the mathematical aspects of high energy physics.

Mathematical Physics is one of the most active branches of mathematics and physics today, with increasingly important connections to other branches of mathematics and science. The project activities are designed to increase the number and the diversity of Americans who are actively exploring Mathematical Physics, Geometry, and String Theory, and to improve the quality of their experience. Strong improvements are anticipated at all levels, with very significant improvements in graduate and postdoctoral research.. The explosive growth of interest in the theory of universe has made this a very exciting time to begin research in the field, but it has also made it difficult for young researchers to get started. This project will increase the flow of broadly trained researchers in Mathematical Physics, Geometry, and String Theory, therefore enhancing the training infrastructure and the research workforce in these vital areas of mathematics in the twenty-first century.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project participants made fundamental research contributions and discoveries on the frontier of mathematics and physics.

 

Intellectual merit: The highlight accomplishments of the project include the construction of explicit generators for categories of matrix factorization, a comprehensive study of generation time and dimension in non-commutative geometry, a new theory of sheaf quantum cohomology, classification of orientation data in categories, the development of non-commutative Hodge theory, construction of duality symmetries for conformal field theories and for quantum gauge theories, an explicit mirror symmetry construction for toric Landau-Ginzburg theories, a new toolbox for computing higher holonomies, a geometric realization of the Standard Model of particle physics  in local and global F-theory backgrounds, a quantization of Fourier-Mukai dualities, a proof of Langlands duality for Hitchin systems, a novel methodology in non-abelian Hodge theory for studying holomorphic convexity of linear covers of projective manifolds, the proof of Shafarevich's uniformization conjecture for linear groups,  the development of shifted symplectic geometry and the associated numerical invariants, construction of unobstructed deformations of Landau-Ginzburg models, a proof of Hodge degeneration for spaces with potential, a study of the global geometry of super moduli spaces, and a proof of the non-projectedness of the space of super Riemann surfaces. Many additional complementary technical projects were carried out and completed by the key personnel and by the postdoctoral scholars and graduate students mentored and trained by the PIs.

 

 

Broader impact: The research activities of the project were the collaborative effort of a team of senior particiapnts and junior assoicated who were directly supported by the project, trained by the PIs, and engaged in the development of new techniques and ideas. The project has supported two postdoctoral scholars and eleven graduate students in mathematics. In addition,t he Pis mentored two more math postdocs, four physics postdocs, and numerous Ph.D. and Master students in math and physcs. All these trainees were actively  involved in the research program and contributed to the project. During the award period the team has developed  and taught several times a new advanced course on quantum field theory for mathematicans, a new course on Hodge theory for physicists,  and a course in computational algebraic geometry for students in the sciences. The project leaders organized and ran weekly research seminars, focused weeks and workgroup meetings, a large number of conferences and workshops, including two tsummer boot camps for graduate students, the inagural and subsequent String-Math conferences, two String Phenomenology conferences, and two CATS conferences. Many of the activities and teaching initiatives were video recorded and live-broadcated, and are also available for streaming on the web.
